unit: Unit 4 | Probability, Random Variables, and Probability Distributions
title: Police Citations | 2 of 2
question_text:
Suppose a local police department decides to track how many minor citations its officers give per month.
The mean and standard deviation of the number of citations per month is $84.3$ and $12.6$, respectively. Suppose each citation has an average fee of $\$115.32$.
Assuming this distribution is approximately normal and citations are independent, what is the probability that the police department earns more than $\$125{,}000$ in revenue from minor citations over the course of the next year ($12\text{ months}$)?
solution:
To calculate this probability, several transformations must take place over three steps.

1. Find the mean of annual revenue:

$$ \text{mean revenue per year} = 84.3 \times 115.32 \times 12 = \$116{,}657.71$$

2. Find the standard deviation of annual revenue. To calculate standard deviation, first find the standard deviation of revenue per month.

$$\text{standard deviation of revenue per month} = 12.6 \times \$115.32 = \$1{,}453.03$$

The next step will be to find the standard deviation of annual revenue; standard deviations cannot be added, but variances can.

The variance annual income is $\$1{,}453.03^2= \$2{,}111{,}296.18$. Add this value up $12$ times (or multiply by $12$) to find the variance for the year is $\$25{,}335{,}554.17$. The standard deviation is the square root of this value, which is $\$5{,}033.44$.

3. Find the Z-score of obtaining more than $\$125{,}000$ in revenue, given the mean of annual revenue is $\$116{,}657.71$ and standard deviation of annual revenue is $\$5{,}033.44$.

$$\dfrac{(125{,}000-116{,}657.71)}{5033.44} = 1.66$$

$$P(z > 1.66) = 1-0.9515 = 0.0485$$

Thus, the correct answer is Choice 'D'.
